title: Tuesday, 21st February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:00am

The system worked

PM11:01am

That's caught us unawares

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Bryce -- are you still getting issues?

PM11:03am

As in tech issues. Not "issues" issues

BE11:03am

Nope -- seems to be okay.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Bizarre

BE11:03am

This is intermittent reinforcement, of course.

BE11:04am

By only working sometimes, we end up enslaved to the system.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hoping for its mercy.

PM11:04am

Hmm. I don't have an pic for today cos i was busy enslaving myself

PM11:04am

So do we go straight to HSBC or what?

11:04 am
BE11:05am

We can do, I guess.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 665.30, down 47 (-6.60%), High: 680.00, Low: 664.00, Volume: 40.01m
BE11:05am

Though that has to be seen in the context of the run HSBC's had

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Which has been amazing.

PM11:05am

That's 6.6% on a £130bn bank

BE11:06am

The rally ahead of time was on all the usual stuff we've talked about a million times. Rates, dollar, NIM, etc.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Today, we get the reminder that HSBC's not a very good bank.

BE11:07am

It's macro stuff that supported the share price, not the idea that HSBC's anything other than a bit of a jumble.

BE11:07am

So ............. everything misses.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Adjusted pretax of $2.62bn. Consensus was for $3.78bn.

BE11:09am

(Though we can play bank-result bingo on whichever figure you prefer, of course. A $3.4bn post-adjustment loss is a good one, for instance.)

BE11:09am

Revenue misses by about 11%.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Sheesh

BE11:09am

Lower than expected impairment charge takes some of the sting out of that miss, but not enough.

BE11:10am

We get a share buyback though! That's ............. actually, it's kinda odd.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Why's HSBC using capital it could be lending out to buy back its own shares when they're trading at 1.3x trailing TNAV?

BE11:11am

Also, why am I typing? Here's Deutsche.

BE11:11am

(@ROTR: we're a broad church here. Calm down.)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

30% miss on adjusted PBT driven by revenues

HSBC has reported 4Q16 results this morning. With adjusted PBT of US$2,619m this is a 30% miss vs DBe and 26% miss vs. cons, primarily driven by materially weaker revenues than forecast (US$11bn vs. US$12.3bn). Elsewhere costs were broadly in line, impairments beat at US$468m (including US$100m write-back on oil), associate income c.20% lower than expected.

BE11:11am

Revenue drag from corporate centre, but retail & commercial weaker

Revenue weakness was partly impacted by negative income for corporate centre (US$621mm due to valuation differences on long-term debt and swaps) which had been more positive in recent quarters. However, even excluding this (and we do not normally adjust for it anyway), the revenues would be a 6-7% miss vs. DB and consensus. By division, income was a small beat in GBM but missed everywhere else, most materially in commercial and retail banking. The company flags weakness on margin and currency effects as the cause. NII rate sensitivity is now slightly higher (US$1.7bn for a 25bps rise each quarter) – though we expect questions to management on this given that 2016 margins fell 15bps despite US rate rises (its most sensitive currency block).

BE11:12am

TNAV 6%, CET1 30bps weaker than expected

TNAV materially weaker (-6%) than we and consensus had forecast at US$6.92/share (adjusted for treasury) impacted in particular by FX. CET1 was also down 30bps QoQ and a 30bps miss to DBe. HSBC has announced a further US$1bn buyback in 1H17 (funded by Brazil disposal) – we expect further questions on future buybacks on the call (DBe 2017 US$2.5bn).

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Outlook revised to flag headwinds in near term

Though the company flags rising rates and loan growth as medium term tailwinds, it also flags 2017 short-term headwinds: restated 2016 revenues for avg Jan 2017 FX rates would lower revenues by US$2bn, TLAC/MREL costs will raise US$0.5bn in 2017, whilst lower UK rates impact US$0.3bn and lower CML income is a US$0.6bn headwind. In all this is US$3.4bn of headwind (about 7% of revenues), primarily to NII: consensus currently has revenues up 3% in 2017. In response, HSBC has updated cost targets (now US$6bn of savings targeted vs. US$4-4.5bn), and CTA charges (US$6bn from US$4-4.5bn) – but 2017 cost guidance is broadly in line with consensus already. We expect downgrades to consensus from this guidance change.

BE11:12am

Valuation now at 1.3x TNAV, Hold

HSBC is now trading at 1.3x TNAV for a medium term target RoE of greater than 10%, and a running dividend yield of 5.8% (including a 30% scrip). Even though HSBC has announced a further US$1bn buy-back today (helps offset part of scrip) we don’t think this is enough and expect the shares to underperform today. Read-across for Standard Chartered revenues (Sell) is not positive.

BE11:13am

And Citi, from the conference call.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

In graphics form for my own convenience.

BE11:13am

BE11:13am

11:14 am
PM11:14am

thanks for that

BE11:14am

So, response from the sector is muted.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 756.20, down 8.8 (-1.15%), High: 758.80, Low: 747.40, Volume: 2.71m
11:15 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 256.40, down 2.5 (-0.97%), High: 259.20, Low: 254.50, Volume: 11.86m
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 236.30, down 1.2 (-0.51%), High: 237.10, Low: 233.50, Volume: 7.76m
BE11:16am

I guess the argument is that you can only read so much through HSBC, in the same way that you can't read much about trading at the South Wisconsin Liquor Store from Wal-Mart's figures.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Anyway, that's that.

undefined
BE11:17am

Stick to results or head into sellside?

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Your call

PM11:17am

I was just catching up on the brutal policing over on the right

BE11:17am

Hm .............

11:17 am
BE11:17am

........ perhaps we can note Sage.

Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 645.50, up 11 (+1.73%), High: 649.00, Low: 639.50, Volume: 1.30m
BE11:18am

A company we rarely mention here, even though it's the UK's biggest pure-tech company left.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

... because it's kinda boring.

BE11:19am

Today we get a push from George O'Connor, now of Stifel

BE11:19am

And ex of Panmure.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Fred Walsh, Panmure's head of TMT, and George O' both jumped ship to Stifel at the end of last year.

BE11:20am

And perhaps coincidentally, WANdisco shifted its corporate account from Panmure to Stifel very soon after.

PM11:20am

Quite a bit of turmoil at Panmure...

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Hope it stabilises

BE11:20am

You can say "turmoil". I get annoyed emails every time I suggest anything of the sort.

BE11:21am

So anyway, here's the upshot of Stifel's new buy.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The Sage investment case improved dramatically once Stephen Kelly was appointed CEO in November 2014. The new chef is transforming Sage into a modern, horizontal software company. He is cooking up a storm. While this has been a monumental task, we think that in FY2016A the risk peaked, and the next course is easier. Mind you, this is no solo act. The recipe includes (1) the unified ranks of c13,800 FTE ‘Sagers’ who now ‘get it’ – a major shift in a once-obdurate culture – and (2) a roster of new software that is gaining momentum and outpacing the ‘circa 6%’ guidance. Restructuring gains are appearing, and we like the focus on cash, plus the ability to execute on TAM.

BE11:21am

Our channel checks indicate that Sage is gaining digital fans at the entry level – a first in eons. Our peer valuation review suggests substantial re-rating potential. Yes, Sage’s head may be ‘in the cloud’ but its valuation is on terra firma, on a pedestrian FCF yield 6.3%, P/E 18.0x, EV/EBITDA 11.9x, dividend yield 2.8% on 2018E. We initiate with a Buy and a share price target of 723p.

BE11:22am

Should also note that Merrill pushing Sage as well.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

(@Bluesky21: George likes an extended metaphor. Roll with it.)

BE11:22am

Here's that one.

BE11:22am

BE11:22am

11:25 am

What caught your eye, results wise

PM11:26am

?

11:27 am
BE11:27am

(I've switched to Evince document viewer, in case anyone cares. I'm not even sure I do.)

BE11:27am

Wood Group, then. As mentioned.

BE11:27am

(@alewis2005: huh?)

11:27 am
John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 750.50, down 67.5 (-8.25%), High: 785.00, Low: 721.50, Volume: 2.12m
PM11:28am

goodness

BE11:29am

A stock that, incidentally, marked the start of my annus horribilis of M&A.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

https://www.ft.com...-b151-8e15c9a029fb

BE11:29am

Was certain that'd shake out some kind of statement. Didn't. Ah well. Water under the bridge.

BE11:30am

...... today we have FY revenue missing.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And a bit of a soft warning in the guidance.

BE11:30am

RBC can summarise.

BE11:30am

FY16 results in line: Wood Group generated revenue of $4.9bn in FY16, down ~16% on FY15 and 4% below consensus. EBITA of $363m was in line with consensus, down ~23% yoy and adjusted EPS of $0.64 was also in line with expectation. Exceptional costs of $140m net of tax were due to restructuring of EthosEnergy ($89m) and charges in respect of reorganisation. The lower volumes and pricing pressure were partially offset by management of utilization, 18% headcount reduction and overheads reduced by a further $96m. Wood Group’s balance sheet remains strong, ending the year with net debt of $331m, a net debt/EBITDA ratio of 0.8x. The dividend of $0.33/share is up 10% year on year in line with expectations; Intention is to pursue a progressive dividend policy from 2017, taking into account cash flows and earnings

Outlook remains challenging with some areas of recovery: The oil and gas market remains very challenging and some modest recovery is anticipated only in the US onshore and greenfield offshore projects areas of Wood Group’s business in FY17. In FY16 Wood Group secured a number of renewals and new awards with some of its largest customers demonstrating its strong market positioning, however, 2017 performance is expected reflect the current pricing environment for work which remains competitive. Yesterday competitor WorleyParsons also reiterated that although the current market conditions remain challenging, their customers’ sentiment is improving and activity levels are not expected to deteriorate further. We think the One Wood Group reorganisation together with the sustainable overhead savings position the business well for the longer term.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

And Barclays.

BE11:32am

While Wood Group’s underlying in-line numbers should give some investors comfort, the outlook for 2017F appears, in our view to be a touch more cautious than we had expected, even given the company’s historically conservative outlook. 2016 benefitted from significant project close outs (US$29mn), which will not recur this year to the same extent, given the vintage of those contracts. Hence, while there are signs of new work beginning to reappear, the company is clearly winning new work load, 2017F will still face headwinds and the tone of the outlook will likely have modest negative implications for the stock, in our opinion.

BE11:33am

And ...... oh, I dunno. Credit Suisse?

11:32 am
PM11:33am

Sure

BE11:33am

WG delivered a solid and broadly in-line EBITA/EPS performance in 2016 on 4% lower revenues, buoyed by sound management of utilisation and overhead restructuring. EBITA was also boosted by some USD29m of commercial close-outs (60bp margin benefit), which WG deem unlikely to be repeatable. As planned, WG increased the dividend by 10%, and moving forward plan a progressive policy linked to EPS (2016 cover ~2x) and cash flow.

BE11:33am

Cash conversion is disappointing at 68% versus 119% in 2015
with rising DSO’s (+11 days) driving a net working capital outflow despite a 16% reduction in sales. This is driven by some large integrated oil customers increasing payment days from 30 to 60, while cash collection has been slow in the Middle East. We believe this is a cash collection issue and do not expect bad debts to feature in any material way given the nature of WG’s business model and customer base. However, we think pressures on working capital are unlikely to alleviate in the near-term.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

We believe the worst of the downturn is behind WG
and do not expect any further significant restructuring. US Unconventionals and upstream offshore engineering are notable bright spots, and we see potential for a recovery in offshore brownfield and modifications as the year progresses. However investors should be mindful that several markets, notably subsea engineering, remain lacklustre, and that pricing on recent awards and renewals has been competitive. At this point in the cycle, volumes will have a larger bearing on margins than prices.

BE11:34am

Given lower than expected 2016 revenues and revised expectations for new cycle profitability, we cut 2017/18E revenues/EPS by 4%/11% and 4%/9%. However, SOTP multiples benefit from peer group re-rating and a favourable USD/GBP move. The net impact is negligible; target price is unchanged at GBP8.50. Reiterate Outperform.

PM11:34am

On the oil price front, note that Brent has been going nowhere -- and Mouselet notes the weakness in BP/Shell...

11:34 am
PM11:34am

But isn't there supposed to be some huge build up of hedge fund positioning?

PM11:35am

On crude

PM11:00am

What a surprise!

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Just looking

PM11:36am

Here's a Bloomberg chart that sort of shows what im talking about

PM11:36am

11:36 am
PM11:36am

For the first time ever, hedge funds hold more than a billion barrels of bets that crude oil prices will rally. Money managers last week extended their faith in OPEC-led supply cuts, increasing outright long positions in the global benchmark Brent and its U.S. counterpart West Texas Intermediate to a fresh record. Speculators are on hold, though, with futures in New York stuck in the tightest range in 13 years and Brent implied volatility the lowest in more than two years, data compiled by Bloomberg show.

BE11:36am

Huh. Doesn't the Bloomberg Way ban the word "despite"?

PM11:36am

Does it?

11:36 am
PM11:37am

What's wrong with "despite"

BE11:37am

It suggests that what's happening is the opposite to your explanation.

PM11:37am

We do this Markets Live thing every day "despite"

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Rather than saying "despite", you should work harder to find out why what's happening is happening.

PM11:37am

Surely it's the opposite of what you'd expect

PM11:37am

"Despite" is innocent

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Look, I'm just repeating a vague memory here. The Way is full of perky, prescriptive advice like that. It channels one man's prejudices unlike any other style guide to exist.

BE11:38am

In terms of sector though, I'd note BP investor day on Feb 28.

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 455.35, up 10.15 (+2.28%), High: 455.60, Low: 445.20, Volume: 11.02m

11:40 am

BE11:41am

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,193, up 22.95 (+1.06%), High: 2,195, Low: 2,169, Volume: 1.40m

BE11:41am

Coo ........ look at Vodafone go.

11:41 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 204.20, up 5.7 (+2.87%), High: 204.20, Low: 199.10, Volume: 24.60m
BE11:43am

There's a slew of headlines about selling its pager service and suchlike, but picking through them I think the most relevant ones are on Reliance.

BE11:43am

And Jio winding back its India price war a tad.

11:43 am
PM11:44am

I was going to say -- this is fuelled by india

BE11:44am

Yep. As per a presser from Reliance's Mukesh Ambani overnight.

BE11:44am

1) the company has
crossed its targeted 100 million customer milestone one month earlier than expected; 2) management intend to
remove their current free promotion and begin charging for services from April 1st. While RJios targeted price points
remain consistent with those unveiled in September last year (we discuss these in more detail below), in an attempt to
lock in and retain its installed customer base, RJio is offering existing customers, who sign up before the end of
March, the option of maintaining access to an “unlimited” voice and data plan for the next 12 months, at a cost of
Rs303 ($4.5) per month. With the introduction of paid-for services coming earlier than many had feared, and these
targeted price points higher than widely expected, we believe this offers a constructive read for the Indian Telecoms
market. In the absence of further disruptive tariff moves, this could see industry revenues return to growth in H2
2017.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

That's JP Morgan's notes on it.

BE11:45am

Which is a companion piece to JPM's kickaround of the figures of the Idea-Vod merger.

BE11:45am

Which it reckons is imminent.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Over the last year we have published various reports arguing in favour of a Vodafone-Idea merger. With Vodafone having recently confirmed talks, we believe a deal is imminent. Exploring the merits of a transaction leads us to conclude it should: (1) see India deconsolidated. This would reduce leverage by a substantial €10bn (25%) and simultaneously refocus attention onto a rebounding European equity story; (2) be FCF neutral in year 1, and accretive mid-term as associate dividend receipts kick in. This also significantly de-risks Vodafone’s returns profile by removing future Indian funding needs; and (3) offer $9bn in synergies as well as market repair. Increasing our Indian 5.5x EV/EBITDA multiple to Idea’s 8.7x (+57% YTD) would imply €5bn of equity upside – equivalent to 8% of Vodafone’s market cap.

BE11:46am

Skipping a bit to get to the hard sums .............

BE11:46am

Reverse merging Vodafone India into a listed JV would remove future funding needs materially de-risking the group. Moreover, we currently value Vodafone India at 5.5x EBITDA (€8bn). With local net debt €8bn, this implies zero equity value. However, assuming the merged India entity re-rates to 8.7x EBITDA (the multiple Idea now already trades on) implies €5bn equity upside for Vodafone.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Operational estimates are unchanged. But EPS rises 5-10% pa
as we now assume that absent a VOD-Idea merger, management will recapitalise India (greater than 5x levered) removing the weight of costly local debt. Mar-18E SoTP based TP remains 280p. Dividend yield 7%, EFCF yield 8%.

BE11:47am

Jerry Dellis of Jefferies also a buyer of Vodafone this morning, I should note.

BE11:48am

"Forecasts coming down, valuation already there" is the gist.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We model Headline FCF +€0.7bn y/y in spite of -€0.5bn drag from India/Egypt. VOD has invested significant credibility in ‘Fit For Growth’. We count on +110bp margin expansion for VOD rump (ex-NL/India/Egypt) and -50bp capital intensity to generate €0.7bn of OpFCF. A smaller increase in working capital (as Spring drag recedes) adds +€0.5bn. VOD is strongly incentivised to keep NL JV levered to the top-end of guidance (5.0x) to max divi income.

BE11:49am

VOD tells us that consensus Headline FCF for FY18 is moving down from €5.4bn last Nov to €4.7-5.0bn. This is not low enough for VOD to pitch guidance at a comfortable level. That means cons is likely to keep drifting lower in the run-up to May: an unhelpful near-term overhang. On our (below consensus) forecasts, VOD trades on norm. Equity FCF yields of 8.4%/9.0% in Mar18/19, whilst offering a 6.3% divi yield that looks sustainable.

BE11:49am

Buy, 220p target.

11:49 am
undefined

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,403, up 3 (+0.21%), High: 1,437, Low: 1,391, Volume: 3.75m

11:51 am

BE11:52am

PM11:52am

Bacanora, the London and Canadian listed (AIM: BCN, TSXV: BCN) resource developer focused on building an international lithium company, is pleased to announce that it has entered into a definitive agreement (dated 17 February 2017) to acquire a 50% interest in, and joint operational control of, the Zinnwald Lithium Project ('Zinnwald' or 'the Project') in southern Saxony, Germany from SolarWorld AG ('SolarWorld'), the largest solar panel producer in Europe. This is in line with management's vision to become a global lithium operator focused on projects with significant value accretion potential and defined markets at both the product and geographic levels.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

A lithium prospect in ....Germany?

PM11:53am

Bought from a solar panel maker?

PM11:53am

Isn't Bacanora a Mexican prospect

11:53 am
PM11:53am

That was going to supply the new Tesla battery plant, i think

PM11:54am

Why faff around in Germany?

PM11:54am

I will stop with the rhetorical questions

11:54 am
BE11:54am

............................... uh. I'm so far out of my safety zone here I can barely see the shoreline.

PM11:54am

· Geographical location of the Project provides potential access to new markets, which diversifies risk and complements potential target markets for the Company's Sonora project in Mexico where a Feasibility Study is on track for completion in 2017

PM11:54am

Sonora is the Mexican thing

11:55 am
PM11:55am

The Zinnwald Lithium Project is located in southeast Germany, some 35 km from Dresden and adjacent to the border of the Czech Republic and within 5km of the town of Altenberg and 50 km of the town of Freiberg.

The Project is located in a granite hosted Sn/W/Li belt that has been mined historically for tin, tungsten and lithium at different times over the past 300 years. The strategic location of the project allows immediate access to the German automotive and downstream lithium chemical industries.

PM11:56am

I'm now reading Wikipedia on lithium supply and demand. It's not fascinating.

11:56 am

chopper bear reminds -- this is a Lenigas play

Rare Earth Minerals PLC (REM:LSE): Last: 0.5675, up 0.0275 (+5.09%), High: 0.5675, Low: 0.5588, Volume: 99.40m
PM11:57am

Good luck with that

undefined
11:58 am
BE11:58am

What have we ignored among the comments?

BE11:58am

Someone was talking about Capita.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 519.55, up 5.55 (+1.08%), High: 525.14, Low: 489.10, Volume: 3.89m
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Contract review update today, resulting in a wee writedown.

BE11:59am

Which comes with an "everything's in line for 2016" statement

BE12:00pm

Which you'd damn well hope it would be, given 2016 results are due March 2nd. It'd be a bit late to warn now.

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

Not often Capita gets to write that

BE12:00pm

I guess they should take every opportunity they can.

BE12:00pm

Perhaps tell us the 2014 figures are fine as well.

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

hehehe

BE12:01pm

Though there's always a risk that they're not, depending on IFRS15 revisions .... but I digress.

BE12:01pm

Here's UBS.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Underlying results will be impacted by £40m of impairments (i.e.
FY16 adj. PBT implied greater than £475m vs. previous greater than £515m), and reported results will be hit by a total of £90m of impairments.

BE12:02pm

This will have no impact on cashflow or future trading, but we estimate it will raise LTM Net Debt/adj. EBITDA by 0.15x. While the absolute impact is therefore not that significant, it still points to underperformance in parts of Capita's portfolio, in our view. Key will be if the company can convince investors that this is the worst of the bad news; at this stage we are not sure.

BE12:03pm

(@Blue horseshoe: none of these things happened this morning, or even recently. And we've done the PE angle a number of times here.)

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Following a 'comprehensive major contract review' as part of the year-end process, Capita has decided to impair some historical assets relating to 'specific' contracts. This includes i) a £50m impairment to assets (that were being amortised over the contract life, implying that contracts either have ended early or the assets no longer are in use), and ii) a £40m impairment to accrued income (c10% of the total carried on Capita's balance sheet at FY15). The charge to assets will only hit reported net income; the charge to accrued income will hit both reported and underlying, adjusted profits.

BE12:04pm

In terms of the results ...........

BE12:04pm

Capita profit warned in December for the second time in six months: we now forecast FY16e revenues of £4,834m (guidance c£4.8bn), EBITA of £585m (margin 12.1%, - 160bps y/y), and PBTA of £518m (guidance greater than £515m). All profit forecasts will now need to include another £40m of one-off charge from the accruals impairment. Capita has stated it will hold DPS flat y/y at 31.7p (cover now down to less than 2x). Exceptional charges will now total £140m, to be expensed in 2016 (even though only c£15m cash impact will hit before year-end). We see year-end Net Debt of c£1,970m, which won't be affected by today's announcement.
